author: newsdesk@nottinghampost.com (Neil Shaw)
title: Northern Lights could be visible in UK tonight thanks to solar flare
text:
The Northern Lights, also known as the aurora borealis, could be visible in parts of the UK on January 1 and January 2 thanks to a solar flare. The Met Office space
weather centre says there is a chance of moderate and strong flares - as well as the chance of a G1 minor storm - thanks to a hole in the surface of the sun.
A large hole opened in the Sun's corona at the end of 2023 and the solar wind radiation is now crashing into the Earth's atmosphere. As the magnetic storm meets the layer of charged gases around the Earth it generates waves of green, blue and purple light visible in dark skies.
The Met Office says there are currently four sunspots on the surface of the Sun which are sending radiation towards the Earth. A spokesman said: "Connection to the fast wind from a coronal hole is anticipated during 1 Jan (Monday). This is likely to give a limited enhancement to the aurora, and also through 2 Jan, with the potential for some glimpses."
The Northern Lights are most likely to be seen in Northern Scotland. The British Geological Survey recorded a massive solar flare on December 14.
They said: "This flare is the strongest in this solar cycle, and the largest seen in the last six years"
A G1 (or minor) geomagnetic storm is the mildest category of geomagnetic storms. These storms are caused by fluctuations in the solar wind that interacts with Earth's magnetosphere. They are typically characterized by minor disturbances in the Earth's magnetic field.
During a G1 storm, there might be some minor impacts such as weak power grid fluctuations, minor effects on satellite operations, and slight disturbances in migratory animals' navigation systems. While G1 storms are considered minor and usually have minimal impact on technological systems and infrastructure, they can still cause some beautiful auroras visible at higher latitudes.
The scale used to categorize geomagnetic storms ranges from G1 (minor) to G5 (extreme), with each level representing increasing intensity of the storm's effects on Earth's magnetosphere.
The Northern Lights are created when charged particles from the sun, mostly electrons and protons, collide with gases in the Earth's atmosphere, usually around 60 to 200 miles above the Earth's surface. These collisions emit light, creating stunning displays of colourful curtains, arcs, or swirls of light in the sky. The colours commonly seen in auroras are green, pink, red, purple, blue, and yellow, depending on the type of gas particles being ionized and their altitude in the atmosphere.
The Earth's magnetic field directs these charged particles towards the polar regions, which is why the Northern Lights are primarily visible in high-latitude regions. Auroras occur year-round, but they are more commonly observed during the winter months when nights are longer and skies are darker.
